author: Henrique Toth
title: Palmeiras encaminha mais uma saída do elenco de Abel Ferreira
text:
Veja quais jogadores já deixaram o Verdão em 2025 e quem será o próximo a sair.
O Palmeiras tem acertado saídas de seu elenco neste início de temporada. Dudu foi o primeiro a deixar o clube. O ex-camisa 7 rescindiu seu contrato e assinou com o Cruzeiro.
A movimentação da vez no Palmeiras acontece na defesa. Depois de negociar a transferência de Vitor Reis ao Manchester City, da Inglaterra, o Verdão está negociando outro zagueiro do time de Abel Ferreira.
Palmeiras encaminha empréstimo do zagueiro Michel
O Palmeiras tem negociações avançadas para emprestar o zagueiro Michel ao Moreirense, de Portugal. A informação foi publicada inicialmente pelo portal ‘Nosso Palestra’.
O empréstimo do jogador de 21 anos será válido por 18 meses. Segundo o portal, o acordo terá uma opção de compra fixada no término do vínculo – já segundo o ‘UOL’, não terá.
Fato é que Michel não está nos planos de Abel Ferreira, que o utilizou apenas cinco vezes – todas em 2021. O atleta esteve na mira do Juventude e do Talleres, da Argentina.
O técnico palmeirense agora conta com quatro zagueiros em seu elenco: Murilo, Gustavo Gómez, Naves e Benedetti. Vitor Reis entra na lista de saídas do Palmeiras em 2025. Veja abaixo!
Quantos jogadores saíram do Palmeiras em 2025
Além de Michel, o Palmeiras acertou mais seis saídas de seu elenco. O último seria Rony, mas a transferência do atacante ao Catar melou.
Dudu, como citado, foi o primeiro a sair do Verdão. Lázaro, que não teve seu empréstimo renovado e voltou para o Almería, da Espanha, foi o segundo.
Em seguida, Gabriel Menino foi envolvido na negociação para contratar Paulinho, do Atlético-MG. Zé Rafael, buscando novos ares e mais espaço em 2025, está fechando com o Santos.
- LEIA MAIS:
Relembre os últimos camisas 10 do Palmeiras
Entre as saídas, apenas Vitor Reis estava realmente nos planos do Palmeiras para atual temporada. Mas o zagueiro foi negociado com o Manchester City, da Inglaterra, por 35 milhões de euros (R$ 219 milhões).
Atuesta, meio-campista colombiano que voltou de empréstimo dos Estados Unidos, ainda tem o seu futuro incerto no Verdão. Abel Ferreira tem dado oportunidade para o meia se provar. A diretoria palmeirense não descarta uma nova negociação.

author: Yahoo Sports
title: La Reunion lifts Cyclone Belal red alert
text:
Reuters Videos La Reunion lifts Cyclone Belal red alert Reuters Videos Updated January 16, 2024 at 3:37 PM Link Copied Read full article
STORY: The French island of La Reunion lifted a cyclone alert on Tuesday (January 16).
Authorities on the Indian Ocean island said Cyclone Belal had moved away and no longer posed a threat.
The lifting of the red alert means businesses can restart activities but residents were advised to stay home if possible.
On Monday (January 15), Belal brought wind gusts of up to 125 miles per hour to the French territory, which is located around 450 miles east of Madagascar.
La Reunion now has to deal with the significant damage caused by the cyclone - even though it proved to be less cataclysmic than feared.
Almost 130 firefighters, 10 gendarmes and 15 power network specialists are being brought in from neighboring Mayotte and from continental France to help.
Meanwhile, they've also been grappling with Belal's impact 140 miles away.
Extreme rainfall caused by the cyclone lashed Mauritius on Monday, inundating the capital Port Louis with floodwater.
Eyewitness footage showed vehicles submerged in the streets and people sitting on the roofs of their cars, waiting to be rescued.

author: Jonathan L. Mayuga
title: Group calls for shift to ‘circular’ economy | Jonathan L. Mayuga
text: A NONPROFIT organization on Thursday called for urgent action to shift from linear, to “circular” economy through community-led action, inclusive partnerships, and innovative solutions to plastic waste and marine litter. Compared to a linear economy, which is essentially an economy in which finite resources are extracted to make products that are used not to their full potential and then thrown away, a “circular economy” is a resource production and consumption model that involves sharing, leasing, reusing, repairing, refurbishing, and recycling existing materials and products for as long as possible. Essentially, it means extending the life cycle of a product—including packaging. The pitch was made by Antoinette Taus, founder and executive director of the group Communities Organized for Resource Allocation (Cora) during a recently concluded international conference dubbed “SEA of Solutions 2024: Delivering actions to end plastic pollution” conference, which was held at the United Nations Conference Center in Bangkok, Thailand, last month. “We must ensure a just transition as we strengthen circular economy solutions to #BeatPlasticPollution. Our oceans, communities, and children depend on it. We have witnessed firsthand the powerful force of local communities in the Philippines, especially women and youth, in driving sustainable solutions. But we need greater collaboration to scale these efforts to tackle the problem at the source,” Taus said in a statement. Taus said a circular economy plays a crucial role in addressing the pressing issue of plastic pollution, particularly in coastal areas. Landfills and marine environments are often the final destination for discarded plastics, posing a grave threat to precious ecosystems and the communities that depend on them. A study by the World Bank revealed that the Philippines discards a staggering 163 million sachets, 48 million plastic bags, and three million diapers daily. The latest findings from the 2023 Rapid Assessment Standing Stock Survey carried out by Cora at the Las Piñas-Parañaque Wetland Park revealed that food wrappers and sachets constitute the predominant type of marine litter, comprising 33 percent of the total waste collected. This alarming statistic is closely followed by plastic bottles, accounting for 15 percent of the accumulated waste. “Plastic pollution threatens ecosystems and both marine and human life. By advancing a circular economy, we minimize waste and pollution by creating closed-loop systems where materials are reused, recycled or regenerated,” Taus added. Jonathan L. Mayuga is a journalist for more than 15 years. He is a product of the University of the East – Manila. An awardee of the J. G. Burgos Biotech Journalism Awards, BrightLeaf Agricultural Journalism Awards, Binhi Agricultural Journalism Awards, and Sarihay Environmental Journalism Awards.

author: Deutsche Welle
title: Typhoon Kong-rey moves from Taiwan to Chinese coast
text: November 1, 2024[Taiwan](/en/taiwan/t-66708568) dealt with the aftermath of [Typhoon Kong-rey](/en/taiwan-mobilizes-troops-shuts-schools-as-typhoon-krathon-approaches/a-70370786) on Friday, as financial markets, schools, restaurants and offices opened up. "We still have to remind everyone that the typhoon's periphery will still affect all parts of the country, especially people in Matsu and mountainous areas around the country, and they should pay attention to localised heavy rainfall," Taiwanese President Lai Ching-Te wrote on his Facebook page. Largest storm in 30 years The storm was the [largest one](/en/extreme-weather/t-19020379) to hit Taiwan in nearly 30 years. It caused two deaths and disrupted transport on the island before moving towards the [Chinese](/en/china/t-18480887) coast. It caused more than 1.2 meters (3.9 feet) of rainfall in the eastern mountains and winds of above 130 kilometers per hour (80 miles per hour) in the Taipei metropolitan area. "There are four reported cases of flooding and all have receded. There are also three reported cases of mudslides, including one near a tunnel, which we are verifying now," an official told AFP news agency. Kong-rey lost strength but still remained a severe tropical storm as it reached the Taiwan Strait. It brought heavy rains and winds to China's Fujian province but is not expected to make landfall there. It will likely move into the open sea towards Japan later on Friday. "The typhoon was so strong yesterday, The trees over there at the elementary school were uprooted. The big banyan tree was uprooted," restaurant owner Pan Li-chu told AFP. The fast-moving typhoon made landfall on the sparsely populated east coast on Thursday at 1:40 pm (0540 GMT), Taiwan’s Central Weather Administration (CWA) said. It moved from central Taiwan and the Taiwan Strait before traveling north. What was the human cost of Typhoon Kong-rey in Taiwan? One person was killed by a falling tree and the other was killed after being hit by an electrical pole, Taiwanese authorities said. More than 500 injuries were reported. About 11,500 people were evacuated due to risk of landslides. About 2000 trees and hundreds of street signs were knocked down due to the winds. Two Czech hikers had to be rescued from the Taroko National Park in Hualien County in Taiwan's east. The north-south high speed rail link resumed operations by Friday, but 57 international and 135 domestic flights were canceled. Since July, this is the third typhoon to hit Taiwan.[Typhoon Gaemi](/en/typhoon-gaemi-hits-china-after-cargo-ship-sinks-in-taiwan/a-69747440) killed at least 10, and caused flooding in southern Taiwan. [Krathon](/en/taiwan-weird-typhoon-krathon-lands-on-west-coast/a-70393175) hit the island in October, killing four and causing mudslides and flooding. tg/wd (AFP, Reuters)

author: SAPO
title: Sucesso da série "Shōgun" impulsiona procura por conteúdo japonês - Séries - SAPO Mag
text:
O sucesso da série televisiva “Shōgun” ajudou a aguçar o apetite dos estúdios internacionais por conteúdo japonês de qualidade e os criadores nipónicos estão a preparar-se para responder a essa procura.
Os fãs de mangas e animes japoneses costumam criticar as adaptações estrangeiras pela falta de fidelidade ao material original.
Mas “Shōgun”, disponível no Disney+ e baseado no romance de 1975 do escritor australiano-britânico James Clavell, quebrou os padrões com uma produção falada principalmente em japonês e elogiada pela sua autenticidade.
Em setembro, ganhou 18 Emmys, os principais prémios da televisão americana.
"Shōgun" Outras produções japonesas recentes também se tornaram sucessos globais.
O programa franco-americano-japonês “Les Gouttes de Dieu/Drops of God”, baseado na manga de mesmo nome e que pode ser vista na Apple TV+, ganhou o prémio de Melhor Drama nos International Emmy Awards em novembro.
A série “One Piece”, da Netflix, de 2023, adaptação de uma manga com o ator mexicano Iñaki Godoy, foi aplaudida pelo público e pela crítica e já se prepara uma segunda temporada.
Existem outras adaptações de mangas e animes conhecidas em marcha, incluindo “My Hero Academia” e as aventuras ninja de “Naruto”.
“A procura dos mercados ocidentais está claramente a crescer”, disse à agência France-Presse Kaori Ikeda, presidente executiva da TIFFCOM, a feira de conteúdo afiliada ao Festival Internacional de Cinema de Tóquio.
Esta responsável alerta, no entanto, que as empresas japonesas carecem de experiência em temas como a negociação de direitos.
Por esta razão, a TIFFCOM organizou o Tokyo Story Market, um espaço para facilitar os contactos entre produtores internacionais e editores japoneses.
Branqueamento
"Ghost in the Shell – Agente do Futuro" Os estúdios estrangeiros também aprimoraram as suas adaptações, evitando alguns erros cometidos no passado, como a versão cinematográfica de 2017 da manga “Ghost in the Shell” com Scarlett Johansson.
Os críticos acusaram o filme de “branqueamento” porque as suas personagens principais eram atores não japoneses, com exceção de Takeshi Kitano.
Da mesma forma, o 'thriller' sobrenatural da Netflix “Death Note” (2017) foi criticado pela sua falta de apego à manga original.
“Os autores de manga são muito respeitados e os seus fãs muito atenciosos”, diz Klaus Zimmermann, produtor de “Drops of God”.
A sua adaptação toma algumas liberdades, como incluir um ator francês como personagem principal, mas Zimmermann insiste que foi desenvolvida em conjunto com os autores da manga original.
“Tratava-se de encontrar o espírito da manga para não distorcê-la”, diz.
Yuki Takamatsu, negociador de direitos da editora de manga Kodansha, diz que o processo de adaptação de “Drops of God” foi “incrível”.
“Todos estavam disponíveis para enfrentar os desafios juntos (...) Todos percebiam a cada passo como fazê-lo”, afirma.
"Drops of God" Os fracassos do passado devem-se em parte às dificuldades das editoras em comunicar os seus desejos aos produtores estrangeiros, que não têm um conhecimento adequado de manga e anime, segundo Takamatsu.
“Mas hoje em dia, especialmente após a COVID-19, os produtores na faixa dos 30 ou 40 anos veem animes com os filhos na Netflix ou na Amazon” e entram em contacto connosco, afirma.
A globalização da TV japonesa A televisão japonesa também melhorou na “apresentação e comercialização do seu conteúdo” no exterior, diz Makito Sugiyama, diretor executivo da Associação de Exportação de Programas de Televisão do Japão (BEAJ).
Isto inclui a participação em eventos globais como no MIPCOM em Cannes, a maior feira mundial da indústria televisiva, diz Sugiyama.
Os canais de televisão japoneses conseguiram vender com sucesso conceitos de programas no exterior, como aquele que originou no final dos anos 1980 o “America’s Funniest Home Videos” [programa baseado em vídeos caseiros de humor enviados pelos espectadores].
Agora, alguns dramas japoneses também estão a encontrar maior ressonância internacional.
O drama “Mother”, da Nippon TV, teve sucesso em grande parte devido à sua versão turca e foi transmitido em cerca de 50 países.
O público ocidental superou a relutância inicial em relação a séries com atores asiáticos, diz Masaru Akiyama, executivo da BEAJ.
“Habituaram-se, já não se importam. Querem ver, querem sentir as histórias”, acrescenta.
“Shōgun” 'mudou as coisas para o Japão', afirma.
A diretora da TIFFCOM, Kaori Ikeda, concorda com a importância desta série.
“O facto de uma história de samurais com tanta atenção aos detalhes históricos se poder tornar entretenimento de massa prova o potencial” dos conteúdos japoneses, afirma.

author: authoritymag.medium.com
title: Revolutionizing Sports: The Impact of Wearable Tech and Software Behind It - DEV Community
text: Wearable tech is shaking up the sports world, giving athletes some seriously cool insights into their performance and health. These gadgets can track everything from heart rates to movement patterns, delivering real-time data to boost training and cut down on injuries. This tech is super important, especially since sports injuries are on the rise, like in baseball where pitcher injury rates jumped from 50% in 1973 to over 75% in 1999. But, these wearables really shine thanks to the smart software behind them. Advanced algorithms crunch tons of data to give actionable insights that can be a game-changer on the field. Sure, there are bumps in the road like signal loss and interference from other devices, but the perks of wearable tech in sports are huge. As we keep pushing the tech envelope, the ways we can boost athletic performance and keep athletes safe just keep getting better. [ Graph source: ](https://media.dev.to/cdn-cgi/image/width=800%2Cheight=%2Cfit=scale-down%2Cgravity=auto%2Cformat=auto/https%3A%2F%2Fdev-to-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fuploads%2Farticles%2Fwtnn5dthirj7wg68a0mt.png) [statista](https://www.statista.com/statistics/515640/quarterly-wearables-shipments-worldwide-market-share-by-vendor/) [ ](#overview) Overview Wearable tech is making waves in sports by offering up some awesome insights into athletes' performance and health. These gadgets, packed with cool sensors, track everything from movements, vitals, to biomechanics. The software behind these devices processes real-time data and gives athletes and coaches valuable feedback. [ ](#performance-analytics) Performance Analytics These wearables help track performance with fancy motion sensors and heart rate monitors, measuring speed, acceleration, and heart rate changes. This data helps in creating personalized training plans. For instance, a baseball player can tweak their swing based on biomechanical data from these sensors. [ ](#injury-prevention) Injury Prevention Wearables also keep an eye on fatigue and joint stress, helping to prevent injuries. By looking at muscle strain and posture data, coaches can adjust training to keep athletes healthy long-term. [ ](#realtime-data) Real-time Data Real-time data lets coaches make quick decisions during training and games, like adjusting workouts based on current performance. This instant feedback helps optimize training and game strategies. [ ](#health-monitoring) Health Monitoring Wearables go beyond performance metrics to track sleep quality and stress levels, providing a full picture of an athlete's health. This helps tailor recovery programs to keep athletes at their peak. [ ](#challenges) Challenges Despite all the benefits, there are still some hurdles: data privacy concerns, focusing too much on numbers over technique, and the high cost of tech that might not be accessible to everyone. [ ](#future-trends) Future Trends The future of wearable tech looks bright with AI integration for deeper insights and better user experiences. Improvements in algorithms and biometrics will offer even more detailed health data, pushing athletic performance and safety to new heights. Wearable technology, powered by smart software, offers a dynamic way to elevate athlete training and health management. It’s packed with challenges that need fixing to make it accessible and secure for all athletes. [ ](#components-of-wearable-tech-in-sports) Components of Wearable Tech in Sports Wearable tech in sports uses advanced components to monitor and enhance performance and well-being. These include sensor technologies, physiological sensors, biomechanical sensors, positional tracking, environmental monitoring, data processing, and communication tech. [ ](#sensor-technologies) Sensor Technologies Sensors are at the heart of wearable tech, measuring various metrics. Accelerometers track movement, gyroscopes measure rotation, and magnetometers determine orientation. Often integrated into Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs), these sensors are used in activities like swimming and posture analysis. Force and motion sensors, like piezoelectric, resistive, and capacitive sensors, also play a role. They convert mechanical energy to electrical energy, measure tissue deformation, and dielectric material changes, respectively, providing precise measurements without direct skin contact. [ ](#physiological-sensing-technologies) Physiological Sensing Technologies Physiological sensors track vital signs and health metrics, like heart rate monitors, SpO2 sensors, and bioimpedance sensors. These tools help assess cardiovascular health, oxygen levels, and body composition, aiding in personalized training programs based on detailed physiological data. [ ](#biomechanical-sensing-technologies) Biomechanical Sensing Technologies Biomechanical sensors analyze movements and forces on the body. IMUs, combining accelerometers, gyroscopes, and magnetometers, track posture, gait, and complex movements. EMG sensors measure muscle activity, while force sensors gauge impacts and load distribution, offering detailed biomechanical insights for performance and injury prevention. [ ](#positioning-and%C2%A0locational-technologies) Positioning and Locational Technologies Positioning tech tracks athletes' movements and positions using systems like [GPS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Positioning_System), [UWB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultra-wideband), Wi-Fi, and camera markers. GPS is great for outdoor tracking but less accurate indoors. UWB helps with indoor positioning, and camera-based systems offer precise movement tracking, aiding performance and tactical analysis. [ ](#environmental-monitoring-technologies) Environmental Monitoring Technologies Environmental sensors measure external factors like air quality, humidity, temperature, air pressure, and UV light. These sensors help ensure safe training conditions by adjusting activities based on environmental factors. [ ](#data-processing-technologies) Data Processing Technologies Wearables contain processing units, ranging from low-level microcontrollers to single-board computers (SBCs). Low-level microcontrollers handle basic data collection, while high-level ones support advanced functions like machine learning. SBCs perform complex tasks but are bulkier and more power-consuming. Wearables use edge computing for real-time feedback and cloud services for deep analysis. [ ](#communication-technologies) Communication Technologies Communication tech enables data transfer between wearables and other devices via Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, or [Zigbee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zigbee), allowing seamless data flow and sophisticated performance and health analysis through fog and cloud computing. [ ](#anatomical-considerations-in-wearable-tech) Anatomical Considerations in Wearable Tech Wearable tech in sports must consider athletes' unique anatomical features, placing sensors on specific body parts for accurate data. Proper placement is crucial for valid readings, with optimal locations varying by sport. Comfort is also key, using ergonomic, lightweight, and flexible materials to ensure wearables stay in place during dynamic movements. Battery life and durability are important to withstand sports demands, ensuring reliable data without frequent recharges or breakdowns. [ ](#structural-design-of-sports%C2%A0wearables) Structural Design of Sports Wearables The design of wearables is vital for accurate data capture, durability, and user comfort, using rigid, flexible, and textile-based components. [ ](#rigid-wearable-components) Rigid Wearable Components Rigid components, like hard casing and inflexible sensors, are durable but may limit flexibility and comfort in sports requiring extensive movement. [ ](#flexible-wearable-components) Flexible Wearable Components Soft tech involves injecting conductive alloys into silicone-like materials, enhancing measurements' precision and stability, ideal for dynamic sports environments. [ ](#textilebased-wearable-components) Textile-Based Wearable Components Textile-based tech integrates conductors and sensors into fabrics, monitoring metrics like muscle activity and posture. These methods ensure comfort and functionality, essential for dynamic sports while providing durability and longevity despite washing. [ ](#popular-wearable-technologies-in-sports) Popular Wearable Technologies in Sports Modern sports wearables combine advanced tech with comfort to boost performance and safety, including fitness trackers, smartwatches, and GPS devices. [ ](#fitness-trackers) Fitness Trackers Worn on the wrist, these track steps, heart rate, and calories burned, integrating with mobile devices for data analysis. [ ](#smartwatches) Smartwatches Beyond basic monitoring, they track sleep patterns, oxygen levels, and more, offering detailed activity metrics for various sports. [ ](#gps-devices) GPS Devices These provide precise location tracking, essential for outdoor sports, mapping routes, and analyzing performance. [ ](#heart-rate-monitors) Heart Rate Monitors Using chest straps or wrist sensors, these deliver accurate heart rate data, crucial for managing training intensity and overall health. [ ](#smart-clothing) Smart Clothing Integrating sensors into fabrics, this clothing tracks metrics like muscle activity and breathing rate, offering real-time feedback on form and technique. [ ](#wearable-cameras) Wearable Cameras These capture live action for performance analysis in sports like skiing and cycling, allowing review and improvement. Wearable tech in sports leverages data to enhance performance, monitor health, and ensure safety, pushing limitations safely and effectively. [ ](#usage-of%C2%A0wearables-across-sports) Usage of Wearables Across Sports Wearables offer valuable insights across various sports, enhancing performance, monitoring health, and managing injuries. [ ](#team-sports) Team Sports In team [sports like football, which consists of at least 157 terms](https://schoolfield.com.ua/en/sports-dictionary/soccer-terms.html) and basketball, sensors monitor individual and collective performance, enhancing tactics and preventing injuries. For example, Kinexon and Zepp Play Soccer provide real-time data for tailored training programs. [ ](#swing-sports) Swing Sports Swing sports like golf, tennis, and baseball use wearables to track motion and biomechanics, aiding in motion optimization and injury prevention. [ ](#other-sports) Other Sports Climbing, swimming, and running also benefit from wearables, with gadgets like Hexoskin shirts, Catapult's GNSS devices, and Lumo Run tracking various performance metrics. [ ](#performance-metrics) Performance Metrics Assessing performance metrics is crucial, with wearables measuring internal and external training loads. These insights optimize training and reduce injury risk, enabling coaches to tailor programs to individual needs. [ ](#injury-prevention) Injury Prevention Wearable tech helps prevent injuries by detecting excessive strain and alerting athletes and coaches. Monitoring training loads and biomechanics helps prevent conditions like ACL injuries. [ ](#maximizing-efficiency) Maximizing Efficiency Wearables track workload, biomechanics, and physiological indicators to optimize training, balance workloads, and prevent overtraining, ensuring athletes train at optimal levels. Wearable tech continues to evolve, offering sophisticated applications and deeper insights, integral to modern athletic training and performance. [ ](#current-hurdles-and-future-perspectives) Current Hurdles and Future Perspectives Ethical, privacy, and comfort issues, along with economic implications, shape wearable tech's ongoing evolution in sports. [ ](#ethical-and-privacy-issues) Ethical and Privacy Issues Collecting real-time data raises ethical concerns about ownership and privacy. Clear standards and robust privacy protocols are needed to protect athlete data. [ ](#advances-in-remote-coaching) Advances in Remote Coaching AI and wearables offer real-time data for coaching, optimizing training, and predicting injuries. Human coaches remain essential for psychological support and mentorship. [ ](#wearable-comfort-and-performance) Wearable Comfort and Performance Sportswear must provide physiological comfort, enhancing performance. Advances aim to increase flexible, breathable textiles in wearables for better comfort and efficiency. [ ](#economic-implications) Economic Implications Wearables' economic implications affect fair play, with high-end tech creating disparities. Ensuring affordable access helps promote fairness in sports. [ ](#innovations-and%C2%A0personalizations) Innovations and Personalizations Future wearable tech includes personalized designs and advanced sensors like Triboelectric Nanogenerators (TENG). Personalized wearables improve recovery and performance. [ ](#final-thoughts) Final Thoughts Wearable tech in sports offers big advantages and some challenges. Real-time monitoring and advanced analytics boost performance but also bring data overload risks. Ethical concerns around data use and economic disparities need addressing. Future advancements promise even more personalized insights, pushing athletic performance and safety to new heights. Overall, wearable tech is revolutionizing sports, helping athletes achieve peak performance while maintaining health. [ ](#sources) Sources: Seçkin, Ahmet Çağdaş, Bahar Ateş, and Mine Seçkin. 2023. "Review on Wearable Technology in Sports: Concepts, Challenges and Opportunities" Applied Sciences 13, no. 18: 10399. [https://doi.org/10.3390/app131810399](https://doi.org/10.3390/app131810399)
